segments.text: It's Thursday, the 18th of June, 1981.
And we are at the residence of Hugo Leipziger Peirce in Austin, Texas.
Hugo, why did you arrive in Houston?
I mean in Austin.
And what brought you to Texas initially?
What did you find yourself doing here?
Well, Bob, this is sort of an interesting little story.
I came from Australia in early 1939 to finish the Australian Pavilion at the New York World's Fair, which was part of the British Pavilion.
And at that time, I came as a visitor here
being employed by Australia, by the Australian government, and met some old friends in Washington.
I was introduced to Katherine Bauer.
Oh, really?
She was on my thesis committee at Berkeley.
Oh, she was.
And I met Oskar Stonerow and Berla and my friend from study days, Alfred Kastner.
So it didn't take very long, and I was asked if I would be interested in staying here, although I couldn't formally do it.
But through various good offices, I got permission to work in the United States, despite my visiting status.
And because I could produce a number
innovative public housing schemes, which I had done in Germany some years back on that date.
And so at that time, I also received, through Katherine Bauer, the recommendation to the Rockefeller Foundation for a grant.
And I received a three-year fellowship
that could be used in connection with any university.

But it was already too late in the year because any university availing herself of this grant had to get into some commitment to continue a planning program because you've got to remember that at that time the Rockefeller and the Carnegie Foundations had given $240,000
equally distributed between Columbia University, Harvard, and MIT, $80,000 each, to start a planning program.
And so it was very difficult, so I decided almost to go back to Australia because it was difficult to get this commitment at that late period.
So...
On my way to San Francisco, I stopped in Austin, in Texas, to be exactly in some smaller towns where I knew some people.

And there I received a telephone call from my friend Alfred Kestner, who was a consultant in Washington, that Carl Feist from Columbia University, who had been hunting in Canada when I went to Columbia, had asked for me.
So I went all the way back to
New York.
And it turned out to be, yes, they would consider this, but for this particular year, it was difficult to get the commitment for the period after the three years were over.
At that time, I stopped by again in Washington, DC, and my friend Alfred Kessner and I came back from some lecture that evening, and the radio was on.
Well, in the middle of the talk, one couldn't very easily determine who it was.
But it turned out to be Maura Maverick, who was a congressman from Texas who had just been appointed mayor of San Antonio.
And Alfred Kessner said, well, that's your man.
So he was hunted up.
And he said, well, sure, I would like to have somebody who is conversant in housing planning matters.
But the Rockefeller people said, no, it has to go through a university.
And he said, well, that's easy, too.
because Homer Pirani, who was the head of the National Youth Group in Washington, National Youth Organization, I forget the name, had just been made president of the University of Texas.
And so between them, it worked out that I was accepted.
Homer Pirani, as president of the University of Texas, committed the university to this procedure, and that's how I came to Austin, Texas, and I'm here ever since.
Did you have much contact with Catherine?
Yes, yes, yes.
I retained this contact because she at that time had taken the assignment which originally went to Louis Mumford to go to Russia and write on housing conditions and housing projects in Soviet Russia.
He didn't want to go, he didn't go, and Kathrin Bauer got the job.
She went to Europe, but in London she had a very, very bad taxi accident and was laid off.
So she couldn't go on.
In the meantime, the war situation had started.
What year was that?
That was all in 1939.
Bad year here.
The end of 39, yes.

And so she, by the time I was in Texas, she dropped me a little line that she had received an appointment at Berkeley to be on the faculty of the Home Economics Department, I believe, on housing matters.
So she came through Austin, Texas, went on to Berkeley, and as you know, married...
Bill Worcester.
Eventually.
Eventually, who had been an architect on war housing in San Francisco.
And the war was started.
And he and she both went to MIT, where he enrolled as a graduate student.
And I visited again in their converted
old apartment.
And as you know, the story is he wound up as the dean of University of California at Berkeley.
Let me interject here a moment, because this is interesting, because when they both returned to Berkeley, they were successful in buying a house at Greenwood Commons.
from an old Stockton family.
And Bill Worcester was a native of Stockton, California.
And no one could approach this old lady except Bill Worcester, who had apparently done work for the family, architectural work.
And so he was able to buy Greenwood Commons.
And there was an old house at the lower end of it that Bill and Catherine wanted to move into initially while they were redoing the big house at the upper end of the Commons.
And as a student assistant, it was my responsibility to do the measured drawings for their house.
And so I got to know both of them quite personally before they were ever actively teaching.
Well, Catherine, this sort of way of record, of course, known, I suppose.
Catherine's sister was in the University of Oklahoma in Norman as a librarian, I believe.
Oh, yeah.
And so this is all history now, of course.
But I kept up with them.
They came to Austin.
She came to Austin several times.
And so the rest is a long story in itself.
But she was instrumental in getting my Rockefeller right.
And then through Mari Maverick in San Antonio, you ended up here in Austin under the auspices of the University of Texas.
Yes.
And what was your first assignment?
Was it as a researcher then?
No, I was put on the faculty.
It was a difficult thing to arrange.
They approached several different groups like the
Bureau of Municipal Research, for instance, and government, you know.
But they were all so set.
Budgets were very, very tight.
Nobody wanted to commit anything beyond three years.
So I wound up in the School of Architecture, which was my background anyway.
I was an architect and a housing person, you know.
Sure.
So the...
University, the School of Architecture, started a conference.
It was called the First Texas Housing Conference.
And so there's a...
the proceedings of this thing, various people and speeches given, you know, in the usual form.
But then, by way of evolution, I taught a course on housing and city planning.
And the architects and the interested people in the city of Austin attended this course, which was at 8 o'clock in the morning, so people could take it before they went to the offices.
And...
I was very pleased, so the people who are now all practicing architects were there.
But pretty soon the enrollment dropped completely, and a year later, in 1940, we were in fact in the College of Engineering.
And the then dean, W. W. Woolrich, who was from the family who owns the National Radiator Company in New York,
who was also an officer in the TVA to replace and build new towns for the people who had to be replaced because of the dam building and the inundation of certain areas.
He was very much interested in what we were doing, what I was doing in particular, because I was number seven on the faculty.
The School of Architects was a very small faculty with a very large enrollment.
Was Mel Roach here at that time?
He came here after the war.
But I heard that the cause of engineering had started a
course in Houston, the city of Houston, under the Office of Education in Washington programs called ESMDT, Engineering Science Management Defense Training.
So I decided I would ask for this, but everybody said, well, what has that to do with the war effort to train

people who would fit into a new production because the city of Houston at the time had about 240 workshops I believe and they had to be traveled 24 hours a day and then they had to build additions to existing workshops and build new ones and obviously housing and transportation all these things were quite important so
I got a questionnaire for the Office of Education in Washington to fill out.
And they asked the question, minimum number of enrollment.
And I said, well, if we get about under 15 people, it wouldn't make any difference.
And maximum number of enrollment, I said, well, unless we get maybe 35 people just way up, you know, someplace.
So it was approved, to everybody's surprise.
And that was the first ESMBT program in housing and city planning in the United States of this kind.
Well, I went down to Houston.
It's really funny.

Each one of these things has a whole history, because the city of Houston, and I have a letter here from Mr. Bloom, who was the director of the housing authority there, who gave sort of an account what we did.
41, 42, and out of it came a graduate credit course in Houston, as well as Dallas and Fort Worth.
Now, ESMDT at that time became, the war started the year afterwards, became ESMWT, Engineering Science Management War Training.
And we kept going both in Houston, Dallas, and Fort Worth.
Well, at that time,
the question of people enrolling in this.
And as I said, we were supposedly getting about 15 people.
The first organization meeting at the Chamber of Commerce in Houston showed up 168 people.
I didn't know what to do.
You split that up into several sections.
And so here we went.
There were all the city council, the planning commission, the architects, the engineers, the landscape architects, the planning people who were there, and a lot of others.
And among these other people was a young lady who came and said, I don't know anything about all this, and I would like to know more about it.
My husband has been transferred from Washington, DC.
He's an attorney.
I'm a newspaper woman.
So she did, and she wound up as the public relations person in the Houston Housing Authority.
But I mention this because it was not until 1952, I believe, when the director position of the Housing Authority of San Antonio became vacant.
And she became the director of the Housing Authority in San Antonio.
Now, at that time, the Housing Authority had about 6,000 or maybe 8,000 units to build, an enormous project, and a number of architects took part in all this.
And she did a very, very good job.
To make the long story short, she wound up as commissioner of housing in Washington, D.C. And Marie McGuire.
So you know, this is sort of an interesting individual.
people came out.

But coming back to these training courses, of course we got all the money we needed to make, you know, bought equipment, bought literature, bought, made slides, thousands of slides, and that was really the beginning of our whole planning effort at the University of Texas.
And then the graduate school on request from both the Dallas as well as the Houston people established a
extension graduate center in Houston and Dallas, and people who qualified for it could get graduate credit for it.
So then the war continued, of course, and I, after I finally immigrated in 1943, because I was here a visitor who had to immigrate officially, I joined the
Navy B-12 training program at the University of Texas, and that was an interesting experience of a kind of quite different nature.
But that got me in touch with California.
The first time I went in this connection to California on one of these troop trains, you know, breaking down in the desert and getting the fresh breeze as you came to Manning, Banning.
People opening the windows and everything, you know.
And that's when I saw California for the first time from Bakersfield at 8 in the morning on a Sunday in February.
The train got into Oakland.

into the Bay Area that midnight, and all day long, it was a brilliant day in sunshine, the nature was out, everything was green, the Sierra was sitting there, snow-clad, and no more such a view, you see, because now it's all smog, San Joaquin Valley, you can't see it anymore.
That's right up the middle of the San Joaquin Valley, then, on that train.
On that train, yes.
Oh, it was marvelous, because there was no smog.
Well, anyway, so that became really the beginning of the whole planning program.
The war was over, and now then a rash of projects came in, all in connection with helping communities.
And I have a whole bevy of catalogs and letters and stuff here.
The first project was a rather interesting one.
It was called the Burnett Plan.
Bernard, Texas is a little community outside of that, about 60 miles out of Austin.
And a young mayor, a doctor, asked us to come and see what we could do.
So we started with our veterans coming back to school shortly after the war.
And we started groups that worked with groups in that little community of 8,000 people.
And that was our first.
It was sponsored by the American Legion in Washington.

because the American Legion was looking for some popular projects, and they had done, of course, the veterans bonus, as you remember, that was a big thing, and then came the community planning, because they had on their board a member of the Economic Commission of the American Legion, and it happened to be from Austin, Minnesota, the meatpacking plant,
What is the name?
I forget.
Not Morrell.
Marmer?
No.
But anyway, so one of the big meatpackers, you know.
He had done something very similar in Austin, Minnesota.
And so the American Legion went around and asked for a community to volunteer, and Bernard did it.
And so the governor, and it was an enormous thing all over the state of Texas.
But unfortunately, then the...
The Korean War started in 1950, and this whole project was no longer needed, and the project as such disappeared in a sense.
But it was quite a thing because the then commander of the American Legion came to us.
It was a big thing.
All these things, these projects helped us.
And from then on, one community after another came and wanted some help.
Now, this was about 1947?
No, no, that is now 50, after the war was over.
I see.
As a whole, I have all listed here.
You can take a look at it.
If we go back to the year 1943, or 44, I guess it would be, the end of June of 44,
Ellen Taniguchi was studying architecture at Berkeley.
And he was in Professor Howard Moise's design class.
And a good friend of mine, a high school buddy of mine, had invited me to the party at Howard Moise's house up on Panoramic Drive in Berkeley.
And that's when I first met Ellen Taniguchi in 1944.
Now, Ellen went on to become
the Dean of the College of Architecture at the University of Texas here.
How did that happen?
I don't know.
Would you please tell us how that happened?
You see, it's really fantastic how all these little stones fit together.
I mentioned to you a little earlier, Warren Callister and my wife Martha's sister had just returned with one of her women colleagues from a five-year...
sent with the Navy in Japan as translator.
And Martha talked her into building a house in Berkeley rather than buying an old house.
And Warren Callister designed it just on the border of Oakland and Berkeley in a little valley.
And Warren designed this very
Japanese principal house.
That is where I met Alan Taniguchi, who drew the earthquake structure requirements.
So, when he and his parents went to the lower Rio Grande Valley shortly afterwards, in 54, maybe 55, something like this.
He settled down in the valley and one day he came to me because I had the urban renewal project in Mercedes in the lower valley.
I had a little office down there and he said, well, if you could be of any help.
And a few years or so later we met again in Dallas at an AIA convention and he said, well,

O'Neill Ford suggested to talk to me about teaching, because he didn't want to give up his practice, but he wanted to come up maybe once or twice a week or something like this to teach, and I got him in here, you see.
Now, from then on, he worked his own way, you know, and from assistant professor he became a full professor and dean.
And then he resigned.
Then he resigned and went to Rice University with our chancellor, or president at the time, who became president of Rice University.
And that's where he worked with Crane and that group.
But he moved back to Austin, although he's still teaching at Rice.
That collaboration didn't work out too well, I understand.
I don't know.
I don't know those details, but he doesn't talk about it, so I don't know.
But anyway, it's a different group of people there, and...
And he has practice here now in Austin.
So it's interesting how it all mashes together neatly.
Well, I understand that when Alan left UT, he indicated in the newspaper why he was leaving.
Well, yes.
So that's a public thing.
It's a public thing.
It was a disagreement with the then chairman of the Board of Regents, Mr. Irwin.
Irwin.
Irwin, yes.
And he took the side of the environmentalists about not cutting down trees.
And they had some public argument about all this.
But these things get sort of lost in history.
Anyway, he made a good change.
became a member of the Houston Planning Commission.
But he felt maybe he wanted to come here.
He is still working all over the state.
He's in the lower valley.
He's all over the place.
Hugo, let's talk a little bit about the initiation of the planning program at University of Texas at Austin, when that occurred.
and the relationship to the then American Institute of Planners and your philosophy of planning education.
In ten words or less.
Well, my background as an architect and housing office, I became active in the German
semi-official housing agency, DEWOG, D-E-W-O-G, in Berlin, and became a regional director for the province of Silesia, Upper and Lower Silesia.
And this gave me, between 1927 and 1932, quite an opportunity to get into the total picture of
city planning.

In fact, I took quite a few courses and participated in any number of competitions, among them the, you mentioned Stockholm, I participated in 1932 in this revitalization of the downtown area, this one square mile downtown area of Stockholm.
And the same for Antwerp.
Quite a number of these projects.
My interest in planning tied to the role of housing, where I earned my first experience with Bruno Taut and Martin Wagner in Berlin.
And so my visits here in 1939 brought me in contact with Mr. Strauss, who was at the time
the director of the column of the United States Housing Agency, I believe it was.
And in fact, he wanted me to take my planning projects to San Francisco.
And at that time... Would that be the Housing and Home Finance Agency?
That was prior to the Housing and Home Finance Agency.
Prior to that.

United States Housing Agency I think is the name and that became the HNHFA and you know various NHA and so that caused me to concentrate on this but of course my background is in design and as coordinator of so many functions in large scale housing I had a natural affinity to the
the demands and the requirements and the academic training and research activities.
So when I came here, starting with housing, with the demands of smaller communities into some help, it grew naturally, you might say, into what in 1958 became the 701
Urban Planning Assistance Program.
And as such, having done the master plan for Irving, Texas as a private consultant, I became supervising consultant to the health department.

that had to review all the planning done by planning consultants for individual cities, a total of about 110 cities, which ultimately, after I was out already, grew to something like 260 communities all over Texas.
See, that figure isn't quite exact, but about this figure.
The state health department was designated the planning agency for the state of Texas.
Yes, that's right.
Under the Housing Act, Federal Housing Act.
That's exactly right, yes.
And, of course, that gave an enormous amount of experience, and our students benefited tremendously from it.
Now, we had everything worked out in 1951.
When I came to...

Back to Austin, after my work with the United States State Department as a special consultant to the United States High Commissioner for Germany in 1951, the graduate planning program had been already approved by the then Dean Brogan of the graduate school.
I have all these letters.
And we were... Dean Brogan?
Brogan, yes.
And he's now retired.
And he authorized enrollment.
And we started with an enrollment.
I have all these figures here in detail, the people we started out with.
When the state legislature put a freeze on all new graduate programs of any description.
They're still doing it.
Well, again, I guess.
And that was in 1951.

And the only way to salvage the graduate portion of our planning effort at the school was to go with existing master programs, like a master of architecture in community and regional planning, a master of arts in sociology, economics, business administration, whatever their qualifications were, with a major in community and regional planning.
Now, of course, that was a tremendous handicap.
We had a few people who went through all this, but most people took the courses and went on in their own area, specializing in planning, let's say, in sociology, economics, and so forth.
Now, that went on until the year 1959.
